points.content: Working on ML and infrastructure engineering. Go, Python C.
Worked on TruffleRuby, a high-performance implementation of Ruby.
Fixed bugs and worked on infra to get the storefront renderer application mirroring traffic in TruffleRuby.
Worked on profiling, optimizations and wrote a blog post that became the top post on HN for a few hours.
Taught full-stack development courses to adult part-time bootcamp students.
Documented and built components for moving to a new authentication system for internal tools.
Made multiple apps GDPR compliant, impacting over 50,000 stores.
Shipped features for reporting Facebook Ad analytics to Shopify.
Worked on building onboarding for the Instagram Checkout app, reduced API errors.
Shipped code generators for partners to build marketing activity extensions in NodeJS and Rails.
Designed a new CS curriculum currently in-use with a focus on self-learning, targeted towards high school students.
Built a platform for coaches and students to track progress for the new curriculum.
Added end-to-end testing with Cypress while working on small features and bugs.
Learned to hate writing end-to-end tests.
CSIA Level 1 License.
Started teaching after two years of volunteering as an apprentice.
Won the honours of signing a bent golden(no sparkles or glitter unfortunately) pole as an Instructor of the Week Award.
Among fifty winners of over 3500 contestants for two months of open source contribution for One Laptop per Child software. Worked in Python GTK and Javascript.
Merged 27 pull requests and committed 2636 lines of code, worked on translations and documentation.
Went on a fun trip to Mountain View where I got to meet some cute GCI winners. Proudly skipped a week of school.
Built a highlighter that sends highlighted text to mobile app in real time with React Native and Python.
End product was a $20 webcam taped to a can of redbull with a beer bottle opener as a 'nib'.
Built a command line tool and Atom plugin that translates JS and Python between spoken languages.

awards.thing: Finalist and Best Use of Stdlib

points.content: Built a native Android app to play a location-based game based on a peer-to-peer SMS network.
Built a smart notetaker designed to integrate with drawing diagrams and doing math.
Built 'Faight', an online game where people can get AIs to compete by programming in any language. Supported Brianfuck.
Made the tallest stack of cups. Only won because our team had taller people.
It's a chemistry contest. Wow look a non-software thing. Did this to impress a boy, who was not impressed.

hobbies.description: Mostly hoop, some silks, rope and pole

points.content: I get really sad when I don't go to the circus space for too long <3.
I've also started playing around with poi and juggling!

hobbies.description: Money Stuff, Wait but Why, some others

points.content: I don't read a lot of full books, but I never miss an article of Money Stuff (about finance)
I'm working through Wait but Why, and a bunch of miscellaneous blogs. A lot of my reading time goes towards Reddit / Twitter etc
Anime is always great, and I watch some of the big movies. I watch a lot of TV shows (drama, sitcom, reality, whatever) though the one that still stands out to me in Hannibal.

hobbies.description: The VR game where you hit stuff to music

points.content: I have an Oculus Quest, plays Expert+
Collected nearly 30 species of carnivorous plants, including nepenthes, sarracenia, drosera, dionaea, utricularia and pinguicula
Grew plants from seed, leaf cuttings and had a custom built lighting and watering setup. Washed and mixed my own soils.

hobbies.date: Did it for a bit and not anymore

points.content: Writes solutions to contest problems. Has authored some problems too.
Helped organize logistics DMPG twice, an onsite contest with 200 attendees from the region.
Yikes this hackathon was literally the weekend in the middle of my exams.
Worked on scheduling, programming of mini-events and application review along with other tasks.
Worked on logistics for a hackathon that supported 550 amazing participants for 36 hours <3.
Personally brought in highly body positive fitness sessions and FREE MASSAGES for participants
Experience Lead for THacks 2, with 350 attendees. Managed 1200 applications, judging and workshops.
Where's my money? News Article
Organized workshops with Google and Mozilla, as well computing contests and children's events.
I don't have much to say about running a startup, but I do have a lot to say about managing fomo and interviewing with YC.
Y-Combinator when you can Not-Combinator lmao
Built a raytracer that could make a Cornell Box as well as things such as metallics, dielectrics and could do image mapping.
This is probably the least on-paper-impressive thing I've done, and mostly involved following a book. However, I think it single-handedly +5%-ed my programming abilities.
Organizes school dances, carnivals, and spirit days.
Builds software solutions, such as matchmaking apps, ticketing systems or websites.

events.date: Sometime soon, when I have time and when COVID-19 is through

points.content: I grew up with hackathons but now I'm too tired and they're not as beneficial as they used to be.
Mentored at several hackathons, gave workshops and judged at others.
16 wins and no longer counting
Spoke about the applications of Wolfram Alpha in education, and how to used software to improve existing study tools targeted towards sciences.
Spoke about Python design history and some weird highlights.
It's very all-over-the-place, but I wrote a loosely related blog post.
'Applied Rationality' camp, 10 days with ~30 people. See their website for more info.
I can't quite put it into words, but it was a very impactful experience.
Learned to gamble and build HTML5 games. Built the classic touhou bullet hell game with a rhythm element for the ultimate weeb game.
